content.statement: aaa-017-pararenal is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Aaa Definitions that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding aaa-017-pararenal helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of aaa-017-pararenal include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of aaa-017-pararenal.

presentation: May present with renovascular hypertension if renal artery stenosis coexists
Hematuria if erosion into renal structures (rare)

anatomic_criteria.defining_feature: One or both renal artery origins arise from the aneurysm sac

differentiation.juxtarenal: Short neck (<15mm) but renal origins from normal aorta
differentiation.suprarenal: Aneurysm extends above both renals, involving visceral segment

diagnosis: CT angiography is the gold standard for preoperative planning
Centerline measurements essential for accurate sizing
Assessment of renal function (eGFR, split renal function if asymmetric)

renal_reconstruction: Renal artery bypass grafts (8-10mm Dacron or PTFE)

fenestrated_EVAR.fenestrations: Precisely aligned with renal artery orifices
fenestrated_EVAR.advantages: Avoids open surgery, lower early morbidity
fenestrated_EVAR.disadvantages: Limited to suitable anatomy, requires surveillance, reintervention

chimney_snorkel.indication: Urgent cases where custom FEVAR unavailable
chimney_snorkel.evidence: Less robust long-term data than FEVAR

definition.@value: Abdominal aortic aneurysm involving the aorta at the level of one or both renal artery origins, requiring renal artery reconstruction for complete repair

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Define pararenal AAA by anatomic criteria involving renal artery origins
Distinguish pararenal from juxtarenal and suprarenal aneurysms
Understand renal artery reconstruction techniques in open repair
Compare open repair vs fenestrated EVAR for pararenal anatomy
Describe renal protection strategies during repair
clinical_pearls: Pararenal = renal origins in the aneurysm; juxtarenal = short neck but renals from normal aorta
Carrel patch reimplantation preserves multiple vessel origins in a single patch
Cold renal perfusion extends safe clamp time from 25 to >45 minutes
FEVAR eliminates renal ischemia but requires precise preoperative planning
25-30% of pararenal cases have accessory renal arteries requiring attention

medicalCode.description: Endovascular repair of visceral aorta with 2 or more visceral artery endoprostheses
